scenarios.title: Flower Book Discovery
scenarios.context: During circle time, a 4-year-old is looking through a nature book about flowers. They've been quietly examining the pictures for a few minutes and suddenly become excited about one particular page showing a giant sunflower.
scenarios.child_utterance: Look! Look at this one! It's so... it's so big! Is it real? Can flowers really be that big?
scenarios.educator_response: What makes you think it might not be real? Let's look at the details together.
scenarios.educational_focus: Critical thinking, observation skills, scientific inquiry

scenarios.source_video: Building Blocks Little School Ladybugs Kaylee 013.mp4
scenarios.title: Block Tower Collapse
scenarios.context: A 3-year-old has been carefully stacking blocks for the past five minutes, creating their tallest tower yet. Just as they reach for another block, the entire structure tumbles down.
scenarios.child_utterance: Oh no! Oh no! It fall down! All my blocks fall down!
scenarios.educator_response: You worked so hard on that tower. How do you think we could build it differently next time?

scenarios.title: Sharing the Tricycle
scenarios.context: Two 4-year-olds are having a conflict over a popular tricycle during outdoor play time. One child has been riding it, and another child wants a turn.
scenarios.child_utterance: But I want it! I've been waiting and waiting! It's not fair!
scenarios.educator_response: I hear that you've been waiting. What ideas do you have for solving this problem together?

scenarios.source_video: Being Aware of a Toddler's Needs.mp4
scenarios.title: Sensory Exploration with Water
scenarios.context: A 2-year-old is at the water table, repeatedly pouring water from one container to another, completely absorbed in watching the water flow.
scenarios.educator_response: You're noticing how the water moves. What happens when you pour it slowly?
scenarios.educational_focus: Scientific exploration, cause and effect, vocabulary development

scenarios.title: Art Creation Frustration
scenarios.context: A 5-year-old is working on a detailed drawing of their family but becomes frustrated when they can't get the proportions right.
scenarios.child_utterance: This doesn't look right! The mommy is too small and the baby is too big! I can't do it!
scenarios.educator_response: What part of your drawing do you feel most proud of? Let's start there and think about what you want to change.

scenarios.title: Mealtime Choices
scenarios.context: During snack time, a 3-year-old is looking at the fruit options and seems unable to decide between apple slices and orange segments.
scenarios.child_utterance: I want... I want both! Can I have both fruits?
scenarios.educator_response: You're thinking about your choices. What would help you decide which one to try first?

scenarios.title: Block Pattern Discovery
scenarios.context: A 4-year-old has arranged blocks in a repeating color pattern and is excitedly showing it to peers.
scenarios.child_utterance: Look! Red, blue, red, blue! I made it go like that all the way!
scenarios.educator_response: You discovered a pattern! What would come next if you continued?
scenarios.educational_focus: Mathematical thinking, pattern recognition, logical reasoning

scenarios.title: Nature Walk Discovery
scenarios.context: During an outdoor nature walk, a group of children find an interesting leaf with holes in it.
scenarios.child_utterance: Why does this leaf have holes? Did something eat it?
scenarios.educator_response: That's an interesting observation. What clues do you see that might tell us what happened?
scenarios.educational_focus: Scientific inquiry, observation skills, hypothesis formation

scenarios.title: Dramatic Play Negotiation
scenarios.context: Two children are in the dramatic play area, disagreeing about the storyline of their pretend play.
scenarios.child_utterance: No, the baby doesn't go to school! Babies stay home!
scenarios.educator_response: You both have different ideas about the story. How could we include both of your ideas?

scenarios.title: Counting Collection
scenarios.context: A 5-year-old is sorting and counting a collection of buttons, organizing them by color.
scenarios.child_utterance: I have one, two, three... wait, let me start over. There's so many!
scenarios.educator_response: You're being careful with your counting. What strategy could help you keep track?
